__Text__.text: If all the forces acting on an object are balanced, that object is either at rest or moving at a constant velocity. Velocity determines the displacement over a given unit of time. For example, a velocity of 4 m/s would add four meters to an object(s position every second.
Define the quantities for a model for a ball rolling across a table at a constant velocity of 4 m/s.

rows: The amount that an object is displaced per unit of time; value = 4 m/s

__Text__.text: In this case, the position is initially

Although constant velocities are useful for systems involving balanced forces, we still need a model for systems involving imbalanced forces. If there is a net force on an object, that force will create acceleration. Just as velocity is the change in position over time, acceleration is the change in velocity over time and is also a vector quantity.

Now let's return to the ball from the earlier model, but this time, the ball is falling from rest from a positive 200-meter height with an acceleration of 9.81 m/s/s, or 9.81m/s<sup>2</sup> toward the ground. Assume that the ground is zero.

rows: New position = old position + velocity; initial value = 200 m
New position = old position + velocity; initial value = 200 m
New velocity = old velocity + acceleration; initial value = 0 m/s
The change in velocity per unit of time; value = -9.81 m/s<sup>2</sup>

In the previous model, you were supposed to assume that the negative direction was downward, which is not always the case. Down was negative because the ground was at zero and the initial position was positive, but someone could see the same system and determine that the initial position was zero or even negative. All of this depends on how you define your reference frame.

header: Ratio between the last two displacements

__Text__.text: Sometimes, the initial velocity and the acceleration are in different directions. For example, if you throw a ball into the air, its initial velocity will be upward, but it will still be accelerated downward by gravity. Just as an object(s position can start at a positive value and be decreased by velocity until it reaches some negative value, it can start with a positive velocity and be decreased by acceleration until it reaches some negative value.

Imagine that a ball is thrown upward into the air at 10 m/s from the ground. The only force acting on it is gravity, which accelerates the ball toward the ground at 9.81 m/s2. Eventually, the ball returns to the ground. Assume the ground is at zero and that the negative direction is downward.

__LsText__.text:
Kinematics

This worksheet is an introduction to kinematics. Kinematics is how we model motion. For example, if we launch a ball into the air at a certain angle to the floor, we can use kinematics to determine when and where the ball will land. Kinematics can tell us the relationships among position, velocity, acceleration, and time. In this worksheet, we will cover movement in one dimension.

There are two types of quantities: vectors and scalars. A scalar is not concerned with direction and is therefore always positive. For example, mass is a scalar quantity because an object cannot have negative mass. Distance is another scalar quantity. If you walk forward for 12 meters, backward for 12 meters, or around a circle with a 12-meter circumference, the distance you have traveled will be 12 meters.

A vector, on the other hand, does include direction. For example, force is a vector quantity because force can be applied in any direction, including the positive and negative directions. Though distance is a scalar quantity, displacement is a vector quantity, as is position. Displacement is the change in position and equals the difference between an object(s final position and its initial position. Therefore, if you walk around a circle that has a 12-meter circumference, your displacement would equal zero because you would end where you started. If an object started at a positive position and moved toward zero, its displacement would be negative.

If you walked around a circle, your velocity would also be negative because velocity is also a vector quantity. Velocity equals displacement divided by time, or the change in position over time. The scalar counterpart of velocity is speed. If you walked around that same 12-meter circle in six seconds, your speed would be 2 m/s, but your average velocity would equal zero for the same reason that your displacement would equal zero.
